title: Prusa i3 steel 10mm upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to upgrade the 8mm bars on my Prusa i3 steel printer but couldn't find any parts that I was happy with so I designed this set to use 10mm 303 stainless steel bars and Oilite bushes as these are quieter than the linear bearings commonly used.

The full set of parts which will comprise both X-axis ends, the carriage, the x-axis servo motor mount, cable chain anchors and various ancillary parts.

3mm cap screws and nuts are used for assembly. Other components needed include:

  • a 5mm steel rod for the x-axis belt pulley
  • a bearing equipped idler pulley http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/152174444568
  • 2x 10mm 303 stainless steel rods 500mm long (for the X-axis). I drilled and tapped each of the ends for a 3mm cap screw
  • 2x 10mm 303 stainless steel rods 330mm long (for the Z-axis vertical rods) - I machined each end of each rod down to 8mm diameter so that I didn't have to drill the steel plates on the Prusa frame. You could drill the frame if you don't have a lathe
  • 2x microswitch limit switches. (1 for left X-carriage and 1 for lower end of Z-axis)

Other parts designed for my printers include:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1959901 (GT2 belt clamp (Prusa Y-axis)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1937232 (Arduino Mega and RAMPS v1.4 case)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905409 (Prusa i3 steel 10mm upgrade)

title: Equerre à combinaison / Combination square
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Nota : the English version is below

Cette équerre à combinaison à la particularité de pouvoir ajuster le réglet avec une seule vis et sans outil.

Elle permet de :

  • tracer une droite à 90°
  • tracer une droite à 45°
  • tracer une perpendiculaire sur une petite distance qui ne permet pas l'utilisation d'une équerre non réglable
  • Mesurer une distance et de reporter cette mesure
  • tracer une ligne parallèle à un côté
  • vérifier le niveau horizontal ou l'inclinaison d'un plan (en mettant l'équerre à plat)
  • trouver le centre d'une pièce ronde

Pour plus d'infos sur le fonctionnement d'une equerre à combinaison, Youtube est votre ami : https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=Equerre+%C3%A0+combinaison+utilisation

Vous devez posséder :

  • Un boulon M4×20mm
  • Un écrou M4
  • Un réglet. Celui dont je me sers est de la marque Silverline. Vous pourrez en trouver facilement sur Amazon (https://www.amazon.fr/Silverline-MT66-R%C3%A9glet-inox-30/dp/B000LFVRK6) ou eBay.
  • Des niveaux à bulle. Vous pouvez soit les acheter directement en boutique pour archerie (http://www.hava-archerie.fr/niveau-a-bulles-pour-scope-specialty-archery,fr,4,niveauabullespecarch.cfm) mais c'est très cher pour ce que c'est, soit acheter un niveau bas de gamme dans un magasin de bricolage et le démonter. C'est ce que j'ai fait en prenant ce niveau : http://www.leroymerlin.fr/v3/p/produits/niveau-3-fioles-old-hand-tools-fair-f02-03-l-23-cm-e1400632680#&xtmc=niveau&xtcr=1
  • Un petit morceau de caoutchouc type "chambre à air". Cela servira à maintenir le réglet en place.

Mise en place des niveaux à bulle
J'ai mis 2 modèles : avec et sans.
Mon imprimante n'étant probablement bien réglée, je n'ai pas pu imprimer correctement les supports pour les niveaux à bulle. Pour vous dire la vérité, je les ai fixés avec une petite goutte de pistolet à colle à chaque extrémité.
Peut-être que vous y arriverez mieux que moi...

English version

First, sorry for my approximate English...

This combination square makes it possible to adjust the ruler with only one screw and without tools.

It allows:

  • to trace a line with an angle of 90°
  • to trace a line with an angle of 45°
  • to trace a perpendicular line at a small distance which does not allow the use of a non-adjustable square
  • To measure a distance and to defer this measurement
  • to trace a line parallel to a side
  • to check the horizontal level or the slope of a plan (by putting the square flat)

  • to find the center of a round part

    For more information on the operation of a combination square, Youtube is your friend : https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=combination+square+uses

You must have:

  • 1 × M4×20 mm bolt
  • 1 × M4 nut
  • Ruler. That of which I help myself is Silverline brand. You will be able to find some easily on Amazon (https://www.amazon.fr/Silverline-MT66-R%C3%A9glet-inox-30/dp/B000LFVRK6) or Ebay.
  • Spirit levels. You can be buying them directly in the shop for archery (like http://www.hava-archerie.fr/niveau-a-bulles-pour-scope-specialty-archery,fr,4,niveauabullespecarch.cfm) but it is very expensive for what it is,
    I thus bought a spirit level first prize in a store of do-it-yourself and dismounted it: http://www.leroymerlin.fr/v3/p/produits/niveau-3-fioles-old-hand-tools-fair-f02-03-l-23-cm-e1400632680#&xtmc=niveau&xtcr=1
  • A small piece of rubber standard “inner tube” from a bicycle. That will be used to maintain the ruler in place.

Installation of the spirit levels
I put 2 models: with and without.
My printer being probably well regulated, I could not correctly not printed the supports for the spirit levels. To tell you the truth, I fixed them with small tastes glue gun at each end.
Can be that you will arrive there better than me…

Le dessous de l'équerre possède un chanfrein de 3/10° pour limiter le phénomène de "pied d'éléphant"

A brim is necessary for the square.
The lower part of the square has a chamfer of 3/10° to limit the phenomenon of “elephant foot”

Molette crantée / knurled wheel

Merci pour ce partage, super boulot ;)

This is a blank stamp out of which you can subtract your own design. The result will be a usable wax seal that can be used to seal letters, invitation, and anything else you want. There are wax sticks on the market which you can use with this, as normal candle wax is brittle. A helpful article can be found at http://www.artofmanliness.com/2013/02/13/wax-seals-a-history-and-how-to/.

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator Mini+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Background

I designed this in Microsoft's 3D Builder after I became interested in creating and using my own wax seal.

Usage

Once you download the file, you will need a file of the design that you would like on the seal. You may choose the format, but know that this 2D file will need to be converted to a 3D file later on. When you have the 3D file, import it into the software that you are using and scale the design to the blank template. Subtract the design from the template, making sure the top of the design is on the same side of the nub on the blank stamp. This way you will know which way is up. Print, get some wax, and start stamping.

Directions for use: http://www.artofmanliness.com/2013/02/13/wax-seals-a-history-and-how-to/

author: RThorpe

description.text:
Reels of filament for the CEL-Robox 3D printer are supplied on Smart Reels. These incorporate an EPROM that tells the printer what filament type has been loaded and all the print it require settings. Of course if you buy filament from a different supplier, then that has to be reloaded onto a Smart Reel. So having bought a couple of reels from an different supplier I needed to reload them onto the Smart Reels. So this spooler is probably not of any use to anyone without a Robox 3D printer, but I've uploaded it for interest anyway.
I wanted the simplest of spoolers and have abandoned the idea of stands. Instead this sits flat like on a tape deck. The two stand holders locate by fitting the locking pins. They don't actually lock, they just restrain the two holders from moving apart. A more permanent method would be to screw the two together at this point - the holes are 11mm (you have to supply the screws).
The Robox holder stand has raised features that replicate the finger slots in the reel - facing outwards when fitted on the printer. The Robox spooler slots into the other side and this is used to turn the reel when loading the filament. I have abandoned the need for a turning handle - it's really a two-handed operation and it's easy to turn the custom spoolers by hand..
I have added companion spoolers for ColorFabb reels (740gm) and MG Chemicals reels (740gm). Although I have made individual base holders, they can each use the same one. The top turning spooler is unique to either ColorFabb or MG Chemicals, so I have created one for each for these.
The MG Chemicals reels have screws on one side and these should face the base and not be present on the top.
The Robox spooler stand allows either a left or right assembly for winding filament onto the Robox smart reel. All filament must be loaded anti-clockwise so that it feeds clockwise when fitted on the printer.
Elements of these parts could be used for someone else's design for a Robox spooler if desired.
Please note that the top spoolers for both the ColorFabb and MG Chemicals only fit one side on each reel.

title: 7X12 Mini-Lathe Apron Hand Wheel Gear Chip Guard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This cover is intended to keep chips from getting in your large hand wheel gears that drive the apron to and away from the spindle. It's installed between the lead screw and the apron where you can see the gears exposed.

You will need to upscale this object by 12.5x or with an X, Y, Z of 84.3mm x 60.12mm x 6.55mm.

I have a Grizzly 8688 7x12 Mini-Lathe. This is the Mini-Lathe "made in China" that many other companies sell. I believe SIEG is the original company. That said, this will likely work on all 7x12 mini-lathes but who knows. That's why I included the original .blend file so you can play with it. The final model has a corner cut out in CAD but my original .blend file did not include that cut. I had to do it with a saw but it took 2 minutes. The .stl file was a rough guess as to where that cut should be so worst case you may need to file off a bit.

I attached this to the apron so it would cover the gears using RTV Black Silicone. Works very well if you clean the backside with alcohol. You can also install screws if you want but you don't need to take it apart or drill anything if you do the Silicone and I'm confident this will stay on for the life of the lathe.

In the picture you can see the part installed between the lead screw and the backside where the apron gears are. You can also see the chip guard I made for the apron rail ways which you can find here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905502

title: screaming meemies drone from: Tom Swift and his sonic boom trap

description.text: From Tom Swift and his Sonic Boom Trap - What do we know about the screaming meemies? The sound in the blitzes was generated by little devices Bud christened the 'screaming meemies.' The devices were pretty clever: if the sound generators were located in one spot someone might locate them, so they mounted them on little drone helicopters and flew them all around the city. A moving sound generator is a lot harder to find than one mounted in one place, and before it could be found the attacks were cut short and the devices flown back home.

author: aaron_seoane35

description.text: This is a modification on the spring loaded replicator. It is optomized to use the least ammount of purchased parts neccesary (i actually used only parts that came with my printer). I removed the peg and widened the bearing space, so it would fit the larger bearing that came with my macine (which is a flashforge knock off of the replicator).

To assemble the thriftystruder, print this file along with parts from the spring loaded replicator file. Take the old extruder block off the stepper motor (unload the filament, and turn off your printer), and carefully pry it apart. There should be a bearing within the old block. Remove it, and set aside for later.
take the longest screw in the printer care kit along with a corresponding nut, and insert it into the far hole on the thriftystruder arm. Screw the nut on, until snug on the arm. Use glue to secure the nut in place(i used hot glue, and it seemed to work well).
the only pice used not included in the care package is unique among printer users. It is a screw that serves as the shaft for the bearing. Depending on the diameter of your bearing shaft, the size of screw may differ. Use a screwdriver to create a pilot hole for the screw later on. the rest of assembly is pretty self expiatory (use the spring loaded replicator video to help).

When installing, loosen the tension bolt before screwing on the arm. Put the printer back together, and load the filament. Slowly apply tension to the filament untill the extruder grips it and pulls it through.
This thing is a remix of the spring loaded replicator by makerbot.

You always dream of an iPad but you've only got an iPhone? You don't have the budget for an ipad but you have a 3D printer? Print the iphonepad and you will be happy. You just have to enter the iphone into the case with the dimension of the iPad and get the feeling!

Print the up, the down part and also two time the heart pins to be able to assemble it.
I didn't print it, I think it's too much of plastic for the iPad feeling. But it should work!

title: 7X12 Mini Lathe Way Rail Chip Guard Brush Mounts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This part is designed to fit on the left and ride side of the apron of a 7x12 mini lathe so you can keep all your chips out of your gibs n rail ways as you move the apron left and right. You'll need to print two of these but no worries of mirroring since this is symmetrical and so is the gap it fits into.

You will need to upscale this object by 12.7x or with an X, Y, Z of 101.6mm x 31.74mm x 10.38mm. With this scaling it'll fit the 7x12 perfectly and you'll have press fit 12mm magnets.

The apron has a 2" gap so you can see right down between the rail ways. This piece sits on top of the apron and fits between that gap so it will stay in place. I'm using two 12mm X 2mm neodyium magnets that are glued into the two circular cutouts on the underside of my part. This keeps them in place but lets you remove them to clean them as necessary.

The multiple holes that are cut out are so you can mount in a sponge brush (what I'm using) or you can glue in bristles. I personally recommend the sponge brush, the same you'd use for painting. They are thick enough if you lay them flat to push down onto the rail ways but not bind the tension to pull the brush guide off. Bonus for using the sponge, once oiled, not only will it keep chips away but it'll oil your rail ways too.

I used two staples to connect two holes and then used black RTV Silicone to to attach the sponges. You can do a full sponge all the way across or use two 2" sponges for either side of one of the brush mounts.

I have a Grizzly 8688 7x12 Mini-Lathe. This is the Mini-Lathe "made in China" that many other companies sell. I believe SIEG is the original company. That said, this will likely work on all 7x12 mini-lathes but who knows. That's why I included the original .blend file so you can play with it.

In the picture you can see the part under my finger. I do not have the magnets installed so I had to push it down but it should give an idea as to where it goes and what it'll do for you. You can also see the chip guard I made for the apron hand wheel gears here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905460

UPDATE:
I will be adding two magnet holes to the front to further aid in keeping chips up front but so far I've carved off a lot of material and I have nothing that has gotten more than half way under the sponge brushes. I posted a pic showing the results. Adding oil to the sponges keeps the lathe ways oiled nicely and helps keep the chips under more control. Seriously the best mod I've made for a tool :)

comments.text: How do u like the grizzly lathe? I've been contemplating on getting one. what kind of stuff have you made?
comments.author: GTchris

comments.text:
I always thought a lathe wouldn't have a place in my world but I'm so thankful I bought one finally. I've only had it 2 months but I've turned down some aluminum rod with tapers so I could make some stainless steel cable rollers for a mechanical tension lift system I built.
My motorcycle mirrors kept breaking on me too so I offset a piece of steel so I could turn down some oval cams. I then welded my old mirrors onto the new pieces and voila, new, improved, more solid motorcycle mirrors :)
I need a tube roller but I need it a larger size so I can do sheeting too and there really just isn't a cost effective option out there for what I want. Well with this lil guy, I can turn out some tube roller dies out of whatever material I want and then build the whole thing for 1/10th the cost of the tube roller I wanted which was not wide enough. Now it can be as wide as I want and I can make all the custom dies I want which go for about $100 a set.
I need to make some fire props as well which I can do basic bends and what not but once I have that tube roller I'll be set but rings are only so fun... What happens when you cut some eccentric patterns or perhaps functional grips? Well you can with a lathe :)
comments.author: GTchris

description.text: Needed one ,so i made one. works really well. Puts the transmitter at the right angle to keep the attenna in the best  position.The unit fits with friction and fits really well,I do have a clip that fits the unit but i would try its fitment with out the clip first as mine fits great. It has the pins accessable on the jr module so you can pickup ppm at all outputs. It also makes a very stable stand for the transmitter and keeps your electronics off the floor  and  you can slip your hand under the whole transmitter on pickup which works great ,its quite ergonomic as it keeps nice access to the transmitter, no functions are inhibited.All runs off the 11v lipo in the turnigy 9xr, awesome no more dangling batteries when the velcro falls off in the field ,lol Overall  Im very happy with this setup and the turnigy has put my spektrum on the shelf as it did not like working with my immersion. the turnigy with the immersion is plug and play now as hobbyking supply the radios with the ppm enabled on the futaba training plug .big Thumbs up from me for the money its a frickin great UHF setup. heres the design should anyone want one . I know there just about to release a version in a jr module which is awesome but this is for all the bods who have this version.

print_settings.Notes:: When you are printing with PLA, use extra cooling or print 4 pieces at once. The form is very thin and overhangs tend to melt down when you print only one piece.

description.text:
After flying nearly 12 months, the lower bearings of the DYS BE1806 on my ZMR250 are worn out. On one motor the lower bearing is finally broken. I think this is because of all the mud, that gets to the bearing by the holes in the ZMR250 arm.

So I designed a motor-protector that fits on the arm without demounting the motor screws. Just slip the protector on the arm and zip-tie it. Be aware, there is a small version for 1806-motors and a bigger version that fits up to 2205 motors. Both are designed for 3mm arms. Other versions may follow.

The protector covers the hole for the motor-shaft and it covers all motor screws. No dirty hex-screws, no mud on the motorshaft and bearings.

Print upright as in the stl-file. Use PLA or TPU.

CTC Dual

No

0.2mm

0% up to 50%

The asymmetrical links provide an interesting and elegant look. The larger loop is about a half inch across and at 30 links the chain is a little under 24 inches while at 34 links it is nearly 27 inches.

Loading
The STL files come in off center and turned 45 degrees off axis. The thing files are loaded properly. Printing
I have printed using default settings (2 shells, 10% infill, 0.2mm) and as solid at 0.1mm layer height directly on acrylic bed. Removing
Use care to remove as the stem joining the two loops is delicate. Although in principle no links touch, in practice some of the links stick together when printed. To separate the links carefully rotate the joined loops in orthogonal axes.

à² _à² 
I needed some Look of Disapproval glasses in a pinch, and ended up drawing a pair and cutting them on my laser.
Afterwards, I noticed Thingiverse was missing the ever-so-helpful Look of Disapproval, so I figured I would fill the gap :)
The idea came from a pair of the same type of glasses I had previously purchased from another maker, Tim Saylor. These are not a copy of his design, but rather a new, hand drawn, rendition of the famous Look of Disapproval.

JUST WANT TO PURCHASE A PAIR?
A few people have asked me if I could just sell them a pair. For this reason, you can now buy the glasses straight from my shop, The Plasmatorium: http://www.etsy.com/shop/Plasmatorium

This model is to be cut out on 1/8in material on a laser cutter.
Acrylic or wood would make a good look.
Once cut, just stick the arms through the holes, and start disapproving.
CUSTOMIZE: Everyone's head and face is a little different from everyone else's. You may wish to further customize your pair of glasses to look better on your face. I would recommend adjusting things like how flat the ovals are, how far out the "eyebrows" go, how high up they go, and even how thick that top line is.
Find something that looks good for you

author: ManelVR

description.text:
This is a work in progress 100mm brushless micro quad with motor mounts for 1104 motors and able to swing up to 65 mm propellers.

Parts to print
1 x Bottom plate 3 mm
1 x Top plate 1.5 mm
2 x Side plate for aio camera 1 mm

Parts used by me
Motors 1103 8000kv https://goo.gl/Ttl9bO (these have a smaller 8.5 mm mounting pattern but can be used if mounted carefullys since the plastic have some give in it.
Esc 6A Blheli_s https://goo.gl/jCGtEU
Flight controller Picoblx clone https://goo.gl/RhHphW
FPV AIO Camera Aomway hb25t https://goo.gl/sarYd2
Any other small AIO camera should work.
Battery most small 2S should work.
Receiver a micro receiver for your radio

Assembly instructions.
Print 1 bottom plate, 1 top plate and 2 side plates for the top assembly. Use m2 nylon standoffs in an appropriate length to separate top and bottom plate. Secure the aio camera between the two side plates on the top mount using rubber band and double sided tape. Pictures to come.

All files have been test printed in ABS using 100% infill with support on a Prusa i3 rework using gcode made with Cura.

As this is a test project I have made just to try 65 mm propellers on the 1103 motors but also for learning CAD and 3D modelling it's placed here for any one too try and remodel as . wanted. Please just leave credit if used. If you get tired of 3d printed frames and want a high quality frame from a good designer I can highly recommend http://rotoriousfpv.com they have the best micro frames I have tried.

title: 3DRC RC Jet Boat Prototype
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A fully 3D printed RC jet boat. Requires a 9g servo, motor, ESC, receiver, and 2-3s lipo battery, along with some m3x12 bolts, some m3x6 set screws, some 3mm stainless steel shaft and a 3x10x4 sealed bearing.

Please respect the license and don't distribute without credit, or use for commercial purposes.

The main hull and mechanical parts can be printed in any material (I used PLA, and PETG for the impeller), but the seals and rubber washers must be printed in TPU or any other flexible filament. Only a few metres of TPU are needed, so a cheap 10M sample from somewhere such as rigid.ink will be enough if you don't have a whole spool of it.

I have designed this to be printable on low end 3D printers, and no parts need gluing together for assembly. All parts can be printed at 0.3mm, but I recommend 0.2mm for better quality.

Print all hull components at a low infill with 3 shells to cut down on weight, but maintain strength. No parts require supports if printed in the correct orientations.

I have added two different sizes of nozzles, 10mm and 14mm. I personally use the 14mm one, but I believe a higher top speed could theoretically be achieved with the 10mm one.
I recommend tapping all holes before bolting the parts together to reduce the chance of damaging them.

Tevo Tarantula

author: finhudson16

print_settings.Notes:: I highly recommend printing this thing so the hex nut sits on your build plate. This ensures the least chance of distortion to the electrode guides. At worst you'll have some distortion on your threads (unless you've really learned how to use your 3d printer ;) and if you do they can be easily re-tapped. The holes are not as easy but worst case, use a drill bit and hand twist them in so you can open the holes up a bit more. You'll also spend less on your support since you're supporting the lower external taper, not the deep internal taper.

title: Beefier TIG Tungsten Electrode Grinder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's a video for your viewing pleasure which shows this in action cutting off a balled up 1/8 rod (which I had difficulty due to user error), a grind of a 3/32, 1/16 and then grinding down the 1/8. This is the first time this tool was put into use as well but it did not let me down just as the previous model didn't :D
I need to eat before I film this stuff ;)

https://youtu.be/RPC9Tmbl3Xs

2017-06-25 - UPDATE!!!
I started from scratch and completely rebuilt this thing. The new files are the ones with V4, but really you probably just need the .STL. I still kept most of JAG's design in mind but I made some upgrades and still kept the beefier aspects I added before.
One new upgrade is I've added a slot to slide an electrode down on and cut it off since sometimes you have too much blob and can't get your electrode in the holes.
The angles are still similar as before but I've widened the holes a bit more so you shouldn't have to ream them out to accommodate the electrodes but it still accommodates 1/16, 3/32, and 1/8 at roughly 10°, 20°, 30°, and 40°.
The threading is done at 3/4 12TPI which is Dremel's standard. I've oversized the threading just slightly by .3 mm to allow ease of threading.
I re-did the overall size as well so it should work with a Dremel without having to add spacers and still work with the mandrel/disc set I suggested. The rods should angle in and sit nicely in the center of the disc once they are completely ground to a point as well.

Hopefully this one has less issues with others' printer software too but I will say Cura has never had issues and I've printed several of these already.

The new file is called Entity Unknown V4 TIG Tungsten Electrode Grinder.stl
I've also uploaded the V4 blender files if you want to modify this in any way. I still kept the originals V1s up here as well.

Enjoy!

Original Posting:
I built this from JAG's original design over at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18347

His works great but it's a PITA to attach since you must lock the mandrel for you grinding disc down in the collect, then put this tool on your Dremel, then you have to screw the diamond wheel disc on.
I added two wrench slots on either side so you can just screw this tool on your Dremel, then use a wrench to lock down the mandrel with your diamond disc already mounted to your mandrel. Basically I got my Dremel back to use for other projects rather than feeling the need (laziness) to keep it as a dedicated electrode grinder.

I also beefed up the point around the hex nut at the base because I've had two of JAGs original design snap at this point on me and gluing is not an option since things will be off center.

I used a tap to re-thread the threads since they were too tight for my Dremel (3000 Model). I found you should only tap about 1/4 to 1/3 inch so it taper and snugs up against the Dremel. I also like using my pistol grip tool for my Dremel to give a small gap for this tool and the Dremel which sets the guide holes just above the disc otherwise without said gap, the holes point directly to the center of the disc, i.e. not functional.

I'm using the TEMO 10 Piece Diamond Coated Cut Off Wheels from Amazon and these work perfectly for this tool with said gap that I created. A slightly shorter mandrel would mean no gap is necessary so I could probably just chop this off a but but again, lazy factor.

JAG did an awesome job and it probably works great for his Dremel but in this case as said I found a couple points of improvement and I also found a couple adjustments required to use with my Dremel. Great job man and thanks for the wonderful tool! Saved me $200-$1000 for a legit grinder and this thing is still seriously legit :)

Here's Jag's original description too which will help you further understand your tungsten sizes you can work with:

This is an attachment for a dremel or similar tool that makes it easy to grind tungsten electrodes for TIG welding.

It has holes for 1/16", 3/32" and 1/8" electrodes at 4 different angles.

It uses a diamond disc that I got at harbor freight (I think)

Thanks to Lenbok ( http://www.thingiverse.com/Lenbok ) for the original design. I'd been meaning to design this for a while but his design did most of the work for me.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.5

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I highly recommend printing this thing so the hex nut sits on your build plate. This ensures the least chance of distortion to the electrode guides. At worst you'll have some distortion on your threads (unless you've really learned how to use your 3d printer ;) and if you do they can be easily re-tapped. The holes are not as easy but worst case, use a drill bit and hand twist them in so you can open the holes up a bit more. You'll also spend less on your support since you're supporting the lower external taper, not the deep internal taper.

comments.text:
I uploaded the .blend file so if you have Blender you can export for whatever format that might work for you. Blender is a freeware install so yeah one of many more 3d apps you'll have on your system ;)
This is the original file just before I exported as well so it includes all the blocks I used to cut things up, the duplicate parts, and other stuff. The "V2 Beefier TIG Electrode Grinder" is the object you'll want in the end but feel free to play with what's in there. If you choose to work with Blender, you'll need to delete all those extras until you're down to the V2 object you want, select it, then export to whatever format you'd like.

comments.text: Works really well, was having a small issue with lighter spools where the filament would jump out the sides. I fixed this issue by turning the spool where it feeds on the bottom instead of the top and drilling filament sized holes through the bottom mount and feeding the filament through the holes. This works remarkably well and gives the spool tension which keeps the filament on the spool.

description.text: This design was inspired by the devices that hold pizza trays significantly above the table to leave more room on the table. The design is fairly strong, and can easily hold a pot of water without trouble. My only caution is that it is somewhat vulnerable to twisting at the top, so be slightly careful when moving around the object on top. I've used it to hold up pots, pans, cutting boards, a crate of peaches, and more. Just make sure to have an insulator in between a hot pan or pot and this.

description.text:
A Tablet Holder (for 7" tablets)

[11/27/16 - Renamed files, Tweaked designs, Added 'Lite' version for 7" Nexus]

Versions:
Astro --> Tablet's similar to "Astro Tab A735"
Nexus --> Tablet's similar to "Asus 7" (Nexus 2012 version). Side relief for Button access.
Kyocera --> Tablet's similar to Kyocera (this is a low profile, more compact tablet holder without added stuff).

Tablet dimensions vary - Adjust for your Tablet's width and thickness by scaling the part. Use the Xsection for getting the correct scaling (no need to print the entire part until scale is dialed in).

Options:
Generic Base and Front inserts (Base can be used for storing Ear Buds, USB cable...).
Bottoms - glue them on (they make it more comfortable to grip/hold).
Nexus Tiltback: A stand for the Nexus in horizontal (& landscape orientation if using the Front attachment).

Printer:

Hictop (from kits)

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

See below...

Infill:

I used: 3 Top and 3 Bottom layers, 2 Shells, 20% infill.20% or more for all parts except Bottom (15%).

Notes:

Depending on your printer/software/skills, you may/may-not need supports for the overhangs.

Use supports for the small horizontal overhang-lip that traps the tablet. May need them for overhangs so, test first...

Clean-up / sand / file the bottom (brim) edges to ensure the attachments fit.
Stylus Cavity: Clean it out if needed - I pre-clean with 23/64" drill-bit, and finish with 3/8" drill-bit.

I printed several in PLA at 232 C to ensure bonding of Filament in the overhangs thus avoiding drooping threads.

Print Height (z) = 0.2mm for tablet holder/other.
Print Height (z) = 0.1 to 0.15 for the Bottoms (to prevent drooping threads).

author: hel

description.text:
Simple wall hook for backpack. One screw only.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SOFUUp5zA1Y
Designed after I 3D scanned a wooden cat model. Made in ABS.

Step 1 Obtain materials

Obtain wooden cat model
Retrieve Projector
Get noise pattern picture
Procure camera
Download VisualSFM
Download Meshlab
Download Meshmixer

Step 2 Take a million pictures

Project Noise pattern from projector onto wooden cat. Take 30-50 pictures of the cat in one orientation by using different angles of the camera. Turn cat, take another set of pictures and repeat until all sides are collected.

Step 3 VisualSFM Magic

Run each set of pictures through VisualSFM until all sets return a good 3D point cloud. This is some extreme math magic, do not attempt to understand.

Step 4 Meshlab Magic

Dump all of the 3D point clouds into Meshlab, repeat until meshlab stops crashing. Arrange all point clouds into a mostly aligned single cat. This will be difficult because picture scans always return different orientations and scales, and meshlab will constantly crash. Once all files are properly scaled and aligned, run a poisson surface reconstruction.

Step 5 Meshmixer Smoothing

Import model into meshmixer to reduce the amount of polygons as well as repairing any misses from the previous processes.

Step 6 Print

Forget to turn on supports, print cat, regret not using supports, make note in thingiverse comment section.

title: Rotary adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an adapter that you can combine two rotary encoders and one push button in one splited knob. You can make combinations of what you need to use (one rotary switch with one encoder or two encoders etc.) There are many kinds or rotary switches depending on the detents and the centers they have. With this adapter you can combine the one you need for your application with one encoder and one pushbutton (if you need one).
It is designed for common and cheap parts that you can find anywhere in the market.
One application is for radio control for example. Turning outer knob left-right tunes frequency, inner knob tunes volume and by pressing inner knob, swhiches radio on-off.
It's up to you how you'll use it. You can avoid the button or one rotary if you don't need it.
If you find my work useful, tip for a coffee ;)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Base.obj needs support only for tray (not everywhere)
Rest objets doesn't require plate support

Gears 4 shafts

I made the gears to be matched on encoders and switches with differnet shaft shapes
That's why the hole on the center is circular. To avoid slipping the gear on the shaft you have to glue it with one drop of super glue after you finish the assemply

Base

The base object has some holes on it.
Look at the according image for their use.
They are to tighten separator and back cap.
You can use small bolts and nuts or tireups
I used the tireup from the opposite side just to make the pictures

Especially for the inner shaft, sometimes when turning fast or when being stressed, it tends to jump teeth on gear. This is avoided very easily if you use a tireup like shown. Circle whole base with it. You'll need a long one or two of them connected.
Don't pass it through base (like in picture) but around it.
For better results lubricate.
Don't tighten too much.

Not how I designed it but why...

Sometimes we need some parts that we cannot find it or don't even exist.
For example of you need a Mechanical Dual Concentric Encoder you'll have to pay a lot of money. But if you want a combination of a rotary switch with a specific number of detents and centers, combined with a rotary encoder then... thats for sure you wont find any.
This solves your problem very cheap and easy.
In addition you have the choice to add a button... ;)

Touching parts need lubrication

Lubricate all different parts that touch each other.

Create your own knobs

After nonstruction you need to create your own knobs.
That's the easy part. Both shafts are circular... ;)

comments.author: MateusOP

comments.text:
Thanks my friend,
I've build many of those but they are already installed into some devices and it's difficult to take a video. But on the next one I'll build I'll upload one.
If you have build one already and it's hard to turn, then you can rub the parts with sandpaper to make them smooth. The more you'll rub them, the more easy it will turn. You can lubricate them with some oil between the moving parts for better result.
You can use any type of rotary switches or encoders (including this one in the photo you sent). You can also combine them, one switch and one encoder for example in the same adapter. You also can avoid the pushbutton or the second shaft. It's up to you. The tire up in the last photo isn't necessary if you want the shaft to turn easy but if you turn the rotary very fast perhaps it will jump some teeth after a lot of use. Anyway if you put the last tire up, don't tighten it and put it from the opposite side to avoid it's teeth scratching the shaft.

print_settings.Notes:: All parts were ABS printed on Kapton, with layer heights of 0.2 I think I probably designed the motor mount and front brace to be printed with a width of 0.4

description.text:
These are the parts I designed to upgrade my Flyingwings Hornet to take a 22 size motor (DYS 2205 2550Kv) running on 4S. WARNING fitting this beefed up motor mount and a bigger motor will make the hornet a bit tail heavy. I balanced the plain by fitting a larger battery and fly with a mobius on top of the battery. The flyingwings Hornet is a great plane and handles the extra weight and power very well, infact a bit more stable than the stock model. This is footage of it flying: https://youtu.be/PQfTC5oNNkA

The motor mount allows for a larger motor to be fitted, and allows air flow to cool the motor I printed this in ABS with solid infill. attached it with UHU POR and a small bead of hot glue around the mount.

The winglets are a bit more aerodynamic, but I designed these way too thick. Please print them with a max height of 1.2mm (6 layers of 0.2). They are rearward and can make the plane tail heavy. I used UHU POR to glue these inplace.

The front brace allows the foam to be removed between the camera and main compartment allowing the battery to be moved further forward. I used UHU POR to glue this in place.

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Notes:

All parts were ABS printed on Kapton, with layer heights of 0.2 I think I probably designed the motor mount and front brace to be printed with a width of 0.4
COOLER 3 WAY

author: aled3

description.text: dban

This is a modification to the Prusa Mendel that eliminates the following vitamins: 6 threaded rods, 28 M8 nuts, 32 M8 washers, 4 M3 bolts, 4 M3 nuts and 4 M3 washers. This reduction is due to the triangles of the Prusa Mendel being fully printed. Since the build area of a Mendel is 200x200 mm, the frame pieces are friction-fit together, no tools or vitamins are necessary. Since plastic is not as rigid as threaded rod, the z-motor mount has been integrated into the top vertices along with extra support. This consumes much more plastic than a regular Prusa. It should cost less due to less vitamins, but the print time may end up negating the economy. It's also unclear how well the design will hold up to wobble on the x-axis. An entire printer minus the extruder can be printed with four plates. Not sure what the print time is...but it will be very long. Each plate uses nearly all of the available 200x200 mm build space of a Mendel. The following sources were used for models:
https://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11838
Parametric frame vertex by Matthew Roberts - vertex.scad

Snap the triangles together with a long strut between each one.  Make sure you have a left foot, right foot, top and three struts for each triangle.  If you put the triangles together wrong...you'll have a real hard time getting them apart without any special tools (i've never successfully separated two pieces with this type of joint, they are always destroyed in the end).
If you want to print out a whole reprap, use the three plates included in this thing.  Print out the topVertexPlate twice, and print out the leftVertexPlate and rightVertexPlate.  The other printer parts are copied directly from Prusa's latest Mendel on github.

description.text:
Restoring a 1920's Atwater Kent Model 30 radio. Don't want to use tubes and high voltage, so replacing the electronics with low voltage FET circuitry. But...hidden inside 3D printed tubes. The top "glass" portion is printed with clear ABS and has bumps that lock it into grooves in the base. Base is plain black ABS.

Trick to hull sphere and cylinder to make shape of tube top from here: https://cubehero.com/2013/11/19/know-only-10-things-to-be-dangerous-in-openscad/

Will eventually build small FET circuits into the base with light and gain controlled by the filament voltage. Inspired by this: http://www.antiqueradios.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=81553&hilit=01a

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Press

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm base, .2 mm glass

Infill:

base 30%, glass 0%

Notes:

Base is a fairly normal print. "Glass" portion is 3 perimeters, no base layer so it's hollow. Very small hole left at the top, I'll work on print settings to close that.
Base holes drilled out to size for 1/8" and 5/32" solid brass pins from standard hobby store material. Haven't tried smoothing the top yet.

print_settings.Notes:: I got the best result printing it upright, sitting on the narrow edge.

title: Marx/Lionel O-27 Track Roadbed Scribe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made a little roadbed scribe that I can use to mark the edges of where my O-27 ballast spreader (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1886250) should deposit ballast.

Easily slides over the rails while holding two regular sized pens or pencils on each side, marking a 12' O scale road bed with the track centered.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

Medium

Notes:

I got the best result printing it upright, sitting on the narrow edge.

I don't know about anyone else, but my model railroad starts off looking like an electrical schematic. Marks here and there, lines, numbers, odd notations; all to be covered in the end. I paricularly make a lot of marks and lines to show where my track will be and what allowances there are between. So it is somewhat important for me to know exactly where my track will be and where the edges of the roadbed will be. So I came up with this. Design was simple, I just took my O-27 Ballast Spreader and modified it to hold two pens or pencils on either side to mark where the edge of the roadbed will be approximately while sliding it along the rails.

author: jroberts227

description.text:
Bandu is a fun stacking dexterity & strategy game with many ways to play. The goal in all of them is to build a tower using this collection of 34 different models of varying degrees of difficulty to stack.

Most variations of this game involve having beans (game money) and using them to bid other players into using hard parts and to bid for favorable pieces.

Be sure to print these parts with a fine resolution and high perimeter & infill. You want them to be smooth and heavy. (PETG is heavier than PLA which is heavier than ABS)

See custom section for detailed game rules.

Links to the official games as seen on Amazon.com:
Bandu: http://amzn.to/2fdO3Co
Bausack: http://amzn.to/2fhlyXY

eSUN Filament boxes come with a hole in the back, making them a perfect game box: http://amzn.to/2fLkQko

Printer:

Witbox 2

Game Rules

Game box has hole that dumps out one game piece unseen.

Players get 10 money to start. (Use Pennies)

Game start dumping out 3 blocks per player and setting them in a common pool visible in the center of the table.
All other blocks remain hidden within the game box.

Each player gets one "foundation" piece, set anywhere but not moved once set. (Make sure to use a sturdy table!)

Each player takes turns selecting blocks to build on their tower, each turn you can:

Either choose to draw blindly from the box OR from the visible common pool. 

*If you choose the box and dont like your pick you can ditch the piece into the center pool for 1 gem and build nothing onto your tower.
   *If you do this, other players can choose to bid war you into using that piece. (if you win then you dont use it)

*If you choose from the common pool you can have any block you want for free, 
   Once you choose the one you want anyone can choose to bid war you for that piece. Winner of the bid war must place the block immediately.

Last standing tower wins. If you have no gems the game gets difficult, but you only lose if your tower falls over.
If you lose you can still affect the game by playing as a ghost player. All you can do as a ghost is haunt people by using your remaining gems to take part in bidding wars. If a ghost player wins the bid war then they place the block back into the box.

Optional: Gem rewards for reaching specified tower heights before anyone else (6", 10", 14").

.
.
Here are links for alternative ways to play

  • https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/554203/good-game-made-great-right-variants
  • http://www.hasbro.com/common/instruct/Bandu.PDF

description.text:
Have you ever had the frustration that the part do not connect due to the fact the angle is wrong or the connectors are incorrect?

I have created the possibility to make your own pieces and mix them with different connectors and angles.

A big thanks to Petitpotame for creating the female connector, I have derived the male connector from it and made the rest of the customizer options.

Update 2018-03-09
A big thanks to @projectstew for an update on the male connector. Mine was a little bit large but never had the time to test the print.
Please find the project of the male connector author here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2798373

OpenScad

I have used openscad to make all the parts.
Download the scad file you need and the male en female connector. These parts are loaded into the model.

Adjust the parameters and design your own piece.

Testing

I have not tested the connector or the printing details.
I will print the connectors to see if they fit, but if you beat me to it let me know!

I'm not that familiar with openscad though to know what all was happening.  i knew enough to change the values and to update the female and male filenames to include the underscore to allow them to be found.  I tried to run the little train that scoots along on its own around that corner piece and seems to get hung up.  just a little to tight of a corner radius.  i know you said this was a work in progress and is a little old.  wasn't sure if this was still something you were working on or wanted input on or not.  I love the fact there are these toy parts out there to be printed.  Thanks for the effort! If i'm able to fix these I'll share my progress.

title: Skull shifter knob for Golf MKIII (M12 nut for fastening)

description.text:
EDIT: I think i did something wrong during while designing this so it doesnt fit a m12 nut straight off the printer, i had to do a bit of grinding to get it in and i wont be updating the design since this was a one off for myself.

I wanted a skull shifter knob for my Golf MKIII so i modeled two parts to enclose a m12 nylock nut so it would screw tight onto the stick and a lip on the bottom of it for the shifter boot.

I then combined my top bit with the skull.

The top and bottom are held together with 3mm screws threaded into the plastic.

As these are they will require cleaning up.

The bottom is done, did some sanding to get it smooth and had to grind some material out for the screws.

Printing it right now, will post pics when done.

This is a mount that I designed to hold my TBS Crossfire transmitter and a 2s lipo to my Spektrum DX8 . It will probably work on other spektrum radios that have the plastic handle. The clips are separate from the main body and glued on.

Also as a side note: Spectrum radio users having trouble getting the rc input to work with the crossfire, the stereo jack on the cable is the problem. rearrange the black and white wires in the cable as shown in the picture and the pwm will get to the x-fire. Also the trainer jack does not source any current so you must use an external battery.

4-20-2017 uploaded crossfireclip_rev_2 with thickened cross section and loop/notch to facilitate securing with a zip tie

comments.text:
hey i hate to bother you here about something specifically quad related.. but there are very few people online that i can see using Spektrum with crossfire..
i use . a DX6 and im really wanting to know how to set up the crossfire with a kiss FC and spektrum..
do you have any guide anywhere that i might be able to check out ?..
Also do you know if i can use crossfire with a spektrum satellite?..
comments.author: sensethingy

comments.text: Well I wish I did have more info for you!  Like you I found very little to go on.  If you hook up the pwm connection the way I show here, the Spektrum transmitter will work with the X-fire.  Note that you will need to use an external battery (small 2s works good).  When you plug into the trainer jack the Spektrum transmitter output is disabled and the x-fire takes over.  My setup is a Ranger EX (fixed wing) with a pixhawk flight controller and tbs receiver.  I would start with the most basic blank profile(I'm assuming quadcopterf)  in the dx6.  If you're asking about a Spectrum satellite receiver the answer would be no.  Totally different protocol and freq's miles apart. You need to use a tbs receiver.  I would also ask questions on rcgroups.com.
comments.author: sensethingy

comments.text:
cheers man.. yeah sadly i found nothing on rcgroups at all .. ill be using a kiss FC i just wonder which ports to use .. i guess the PWM ports 5 and 6 .. ? ..
and how did you configure the spektrum radio to see the xfire ? anything special needed?
thanks again man .. i really do look forward to using xfire on my quads !
comments.author: K_Sherman

comments.text: I've never used the kiss fc, so I can't say but I do use the serial output between the x-fire rx and the pixhawk.  This way all your channels go thru 1 wire.  Again, not sure how to implement this with that controller.  You will need to make a profile for your model in the DX6 just like you would any other to start with.  The spektrum doesn't see the x-fire tx.  As soon as you plug the x-fire into the trainer port the control inputs are rerouted to the x-fire (just like if you plug in a usb flight sim adapter cable).   Look at the picture above and rearrange the wires to match what I have (white, red, black).  Out of the box the ground was not contacting the right spot on the stereo jack.

Intro

This project is intended to make a 3d printed cigarette lighter (insert) similar, and compatible with, Zippo brand lighters. The lighter of course uses lighter fluid and not gas.  
Why no windguard? During testing it caught fire.   
Did I mention this print is probably extremely dangerous since plastic for the most part is flammable?
Parts List

• OpenLighter (printed)
  • Latch (printed or metal Zippo Latch)
  • Pins (printed)
  • Flint Wheel (from Zippo)
  • Cotton
  • Wick (Zippo or compatible)
  • Flint Spring
  • Outer casing (Zippo)
    • Read assembly instructions for more details.
Use

Use as a lighter. I'm fairly certain this is a major fire hazard. Fill something flammable with flammable liquid and light it on fire? Probably not a good idea, but make it and see!  
It is not my fault if you burn down a small town due to inability to use common sense in the contruction of this lighter.
Future

There is no latch spring yet, which is needed to hold the external casing shut. It will be added in V2 along with the outer casing.  
Very much a work in progress, don't expect perfection.
Change List
v1: Initial release
Print everything 1 shell 100% infil. Walls on the lighter are thin, so 100% is for sure needed.

comments.text: Note that cheap plastic lighters are made of flammable plastic AND store pressurized flammable gas.

description.text:
Another spool holder for the Replicator 'Dual' and the Creator by CTC (other Makerbot clones as well of course).
Like it was done elsewhere, the spool is not placed on a axle but runs on rolls, for easy and quick changing. For rolls I am using ball bearings (diameter 15 mm, bore 6 mm), which are held by "forks". Per filament roll two holders have to be printed.

There are three versions for either the CTC Creator or the Makerbot Replicator Dual: One where You have to add an axle yourself (6 mm diameter) and two versions that include some pins for holding the ball bearing.

For the versions with the pins/axles included use a hot air gun to heat up the forks. Once done, bend the branches of the forks a little bit until You can insert the ball bearings and restore the branches again. If You got the forks too tight and the bearing won't turn just re-heat the plastic and bent it so that the bearings fit.

ERRATA:
Although seemingly CTC have meticuously copied the Replicator they have chosen another width for the frame on top: in CTC it's 45 mm whereas in the Replicator it's something like 47 mm. So the files I published will not fit (well, not really).

I'll add some other files but I'll give it a try first ;)

comments.text: You should not use any cooling with ABS, if you cool ABS it will delaminate even more. Rotate the model so the flat side is on the bed, and make sure your bed is heated to about 100C. This will prevent the delamination.

title: Parametric Peristaltic Pump with optional mount and roller holes

description.text:
This is a remix of Drmn4ea's Parametric Peristaltic Pump (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454702/). Changes I've made:

  • Optional bottom mount.
  • Optional holes in the planetary rollers. Using inserts (e.g. short pieces of PVC or metal pipe) saves printing volume and might make the rollers stronger for larger prints.
  • Modified formula so the outer diameter is exactly the input OD, instead of slightly bigger.
  • Modified formula so the exit holes line up better.
  • Modified settings so circumferances are modelled more smoothly for larger models. This does however make rendering slower.

I've included two STL files: one design for a 1 l/min pump (using 10mm hose) and one for a 10 l/min pump (using 24mm hose). The rollers in these designs are relatively large. Although this can lower the volume pumped a bit, it can also make it run more smoothly and decrease hose wear. Furthermore, it creates a larger gear reduction, which is useful when driving it with a high RPM but low torque motor. The gear ratio can be calculated using the following formula:

  • Ratio = 1 : (1+(n_sun+2*n_plan)/n_sun)
    where n_sun is the amount of teeth on the sun gear and n_plan is the amount of teeth on each planetary gear (roller).

//// TODO:
//// - Fix leftover plane of top sun gear when using a max. overhang angle
//// - Fix leftover plane of top ring gear when using a max. overhang angle

1 l/min pump

This included STL file is for a pump designed to pump up to 1.0 liter per minute. The required hose is 10mm silicone tubing of 1mm thickness. The outer diameter of the pump is 100mm and the height is 25mm. The holes in the rollers are made for glueing in 20mm PVC pipe inserts.

Gear ratio: 6:1.

Predicted pump output at different input shaft speeds:

  • 50 RPM: 83 ml/min
  • 100 RPM: 167 ml/min
  • 250 RPM: 417 ml/min
  • 600 RPM: 1000 ml/min
    Higher RPMs may be possible.
10 l/min pump

This included STL file is for a pump designed to pump up to 10 liter per minute. The required hose is 24mm silicone tubing of 2mm thickness. The outer diameter of the pump is 180mm and the height is 55mm. The holes in the rollers are made for glueing in 50mm PVC pipe inserts.

Gear ratio: 10:1.

Predicted pump output at different input shaft speeds:

  • 100 RPM: 1.0 l/min
  • 250 RPM: 2.5 l/min
  • 500 RPM: 5.0 l/min
  • 1000 RPM: 10.0 l/min
    Higher RPMs may be possible.

title: Ridget Extruder Holder Mount for MK8 on Prusa i3 - new with cooling duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated Version with cooling duct on the rear!

This Extruder holder solves the following problems other constructions suffer from

  • It holds the extruder firmly in place. The acceleration of the x axis can neither cause a tilting motion of the extruder nor slipping.
  • It provides airflow around the stator of the stepper motor for cooling purpose. This prevents deformation (see picture).
  • It makes it easy to mount and unmount the extruder, even if it is already wired.
  • A Support for an cable loop is provided

The newly added cooling duct provides an cooling option to the construction. It can't compete with an dedicated part cooling assembly but it helps a lot on critical parts. To obtain optimal results it is useful to rotate the printed object in the slicer to make sure the airflow reaches the critical areas of your print.

Printing and Assembly
Choose the right brackets for your Extruder. There are two types of brackets provided. On for using 3mm threaded rods (witch I recommend) and one for 40mm M3 Screws. Both types are provided with different indents on one side to fit different length of stepper motors. Use the 1.5 mm indent ones next to the extruder if the flange has an thickness of 7mm. On the other side choose on witch fits your stepper.

For additional insulation use aluminum adhesive tape as shown in the pictures.

Use the mounting holes as shown in the pictures. The lower holes can be used for additional strength. Drill a hole through the carrier and either use nuts on the back or screw directly in to the plastic.

Screw in the fan bracket from the left using an 20mm screw. The Fan bracket acts also as the mounting point for the cable loop.

Insert the extruder. Bind the cables together with spiral hose (Drag chains are overestimated). Fixate the cables with an cable tie to the fan bracket.

=> See also my other Prusa i3 reworks in my Collection

=> This Part is used in my Prusa i3 Master Rework

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

Use ABS. PLA wouldn't handle the temperature of the extruder.

Choose the right brackets for your Extruder. There are two types of brackets provided. On for using 3mm threaded rods (witch I recommend) and one for 40mm M3 Screws. Both types are provided with different indents on one side to fit different length of stepper motors. Use the 1.5 mm indent ones next to the extruder if the flange has an thickness of 7mm. On the other side choose on witch fits your stepper.

Print the part upright, as shown. Support structure is not needed. Give it a gentle touch with the file and some sanding. Cover the areas witch are most exposed to heat with aliminium. Adhesiv tape is a convenient solution. But you can also glue on aluminium folie with epoxy. Screw in the threaded rods with an electric drill. Use the mounting holes in the X carrier for the upper holes on the extruder holder. Drill additional holes below. Hook the fan bracked in to the hole in the fan and insert the Extruder to the holder Mounted with the new wiring. New wiring. (The wires are still to long for proper action) Deformation on my old extruder holder (after 2 month). The stepper runs usualy at around 50°C.

title: FlySight  SpeXman One (SPX01) FPV Video Goggles Faceplate add on

description.text:
Hi FlySight FPV goggles owners,

I don't know about you but I like very much my goggles.
The only two negative things I found were:

1- The lack of integrated DVR which is essential for safety when you crash and need to look for your quad and for tracking your FPV piloting improvement.

2- Not so comfort. Anyway to my face.

I found easycap to be a fair solution although integrated DVR will reduce the cable mess so this fixes the DVR lack

For the comfort I designed a printed Faceplate which improves wonderfully the comfort.

For this faceplate upgrade you will need:

3D printer to print the plate

Laser cut or hobby knife to cut out the foams

4 1.5mm*4-6 screws: http://bit.ly/2g7FUAu

8-10mm Foam - semi hard
8-10mm Foam - soft

So:

  1. Print the faceplate and the little parts
  2. Lasercut or cut out the foams
  3. Possession the faceplate as described in the image
  4. Add the little parts to secure the faceplate with the 1.5mm screws
  5. Add glue and then apply the hard foam
  6. Add glue and then apply the soft foam

Enjoy!

Printer:

Tevo

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1, 0.2

comments.text: My brother.. email flysight and you can get the premium leather faceplate and foam version shipped to you rather inexpensively. The goggle versions come with both the leather and the foam faceplates, and even the original now does too. They have been very helpful and super responsive. Appreciate the effort you put into this though.
comments.author: anansi22

comments.text:
Thanks for the info.
I been told by Flysight that my spx01 can't adapt the face plate because it has been designed for spx02 which is slightly different and have a little add on that prevent it to be added to the first model batch. If you are lucky and it seems you are you got the batch that you can fit the faceplate.
comments.author: anansi22

comments.text: You know what? I think I know the issue. You may have an early version of the spexman one. The versions I have are nearly identical with the 02 being just a tiny bit wider. The early spexman one didn't have a cutout by the nose I think, that's why the faceplate doesn't fit. Would have to see yours to compare it to my version 01 to see why it wouldn't work.
comments.author: DAquad

comments.text: You're completely right,  thats what I meant.  The first batch doesn't fit Flysight  faceplate.
comments.author: anansi22

This is a modification to the RPI2-Bottom_8020 Mount Made by 0110-M-P (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740/#files). You can use any of the RPI2 Tops from him for this.

I stretched out the screw hole mounts to fit my Qidi Tech 1 for use as an OctoPrint Server. You will need 2 M4 x 10 screws to mount it. You should have some extra in the spare parts box that came with the printer.

Measurements between the two screw hole centers are 140mm. These are found on all corners of the Qidi Tech 1 so you have plenty of options. I chose the corner showed because that's where I want to mount my pi cam using this design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1667505 and a 12inch ribbon.

(Updated - added 2 and 3 bin drawers)
This is a stackable 100mm cubed Drawer system.

Features:

  1. 4 ~ 42x42x98mm drawers with finger slots and handles with jimping "grooves" to help insertion and extraction of drawer.
  2. ~100x100x100mm cube with holes cut-out in back to help with extraction of drawers and one outward tapered face to allow stackability.

print_settings.Notes:: no support needed, you need heated bed since part is rather thin and long so it will warp without heated bed.

title: X-carriage for Flex3Drive for wanhao duplicator, malyan m150 and similar i3 clones

description.text:
X-Carriage (for Wanhao Duplicator I3, Malyan M150 and similar I3 clones) that can carry dual flex3drive extruder drive.

source "files" (onshape)

I'm using this flex3drive dual driver with 2 hexagons (one 1.75mm other 3.00mm) and am now moving that assembly to the M150

UPDATE: uploaded new stl, 1mm shorter "lip" for better seating of the extruder

Interesting note, the 50% infill printed part in ABS is still noticeably lighter then original iron bracket :D

Printer:

self made

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

50%

Notes:

thick layers for stronger part .. 0.25-0.3mm works great, crank your temp to upper max that prints good with your filament so you get good layer adhesion.

note that part is "thick", probably "too strong" for what it needs to hold but I never liked the thin flimsy stuff that shakes and breaks :D

no support needed, you need heated bed since part is rather thin and long so it will warp without heated bed.

if your part warp slightly, you can heat the part up and straighten it by screwing it to a piece of wood .. even better if you screw it and then slowly heat it and tighten the screws so you flatten it properly :D

the screw holes for mounting the x-carriage to the bearings expect an M4 washer and a standard hex (allen) head m4 screw. use washer will hex screws! the original flat head screws might be long enough to fit, since head is bigger then for hex screw flat head ones can go without washer. mine original screws were just long enough so I used them (they screw in to the nuts in the bearings more then 2 turns - enough :D ). would be good to use thread lock on those crews going into bearings (mine were thread locked originally on m150) since the head "vibrates" or you will have to re-tighten them from time to time

the small holes I made to fit my metal thread inserts that I "heat-fit" into the part but you can use m3/m4 nuts..

UPDATE: I planned on using metal inserts for small holes but the m2 screws threaded nicely directly into plastic and both limit switch and cable chain are very secure .. maybe in time if cable chain connection become loose I push inserts in but it looks like for now this works by threading small ones directly to plastic :D

remixed_from.author: Singh336
remixed_from.title: Rostock Max V2 TPE / Ninjaflex Custom Extruder for soft filaments

description.text:
NOTE: I've deprecated this version and added a new one. The post where the bearing mounts on the lever arm can weaken and break off after a couple hundred hours of printing. I've updated the design to use a 3mm screw to mount the bearing to the lever. Much stronger and will last forever.
Find the updated version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2013618

After experiencing a very, very high failure rate when printing Ninjaflex, I decided to go look for a solution. That's when I came across the extruder made by Singh336. It was good extruder indeed and I was able to successfully print both Ninjaflex and TPU. But, when I tried a TPE 80A filament, it jammed in the extruder the same way NInjaflex does with the stock EZStruder. TPE 80A is softer and more flexable than Ninjaflex

I felt there were also a few deficiencies in Singh336's extruder so I decided to create my own. While mine is created from scratch, it is heavily based on the design by Singh336.

Benefits:

  1. The lever arm won't twist like the stock lever arm.
  2. The Knob has a flattened spot to perfectly fit the stepper shaft.
  3. It has a mount.
  4. The feeder hole is closer and better aligned with the hob roller and bearing.
  5. The spring block is closer to the lever providing a more compressed spring and increased pressure on filament.
  6. The filament entry is taller and funnel shaped making it much easier to insert filament.
  7. All parts can be printed without supports.

Suggestions:
The lever arm must be strong and stiff. I recommend a high infill setting with honeycomb pattern..
The knob is a very tight fight and may require a little bit of filing to get it on.
Use an 8mm socket and screwdriver style handle to screw the pressure fitting into the hole.

Hardware:
3 - M3 x 8mm screws
1 - M3 X 25mm screw
4 - M3 washers
2 - #6 X 1.5 inch screws (for mounting. Or just reuse the original screws, but they are a bit long)
2 - #6 locknuts (can re-use original locknuts)
1 - 3x10x4 mm bearing (just re-use the original bearing from the lever arm)

Results:
I've successfully completed a 3 hour print with TPE 80A and the results are most excellent.

I had to move my Day-1 PS4 model to another location and the way my IKEA TV cabinet is designed, it was preventing the PS4 hot air exhaust to do a good job.

So I designed this. Once your parts are securely screwed in place, you should be able to slide your PS4 in and out without restriction.

I made the design so it fits a Wanhao Duplicator i3 bed when you place the part at an angle.

author: jonahasher

print_settings.Notes:: The extruder idler is under considerable constant pressure.  Accordingly I recommend stronger materials such as ABS or PTEG rather than PLA.

description.text:
23 January 2017 Update:
Increased the diameter of the large hole on the Extruder Top (Version v1). This facilitates drive gear cleaning and debris cleanout. Reduce the PTFE connector hole diameter to 9mm to allow for better tap engagement.

22 November 2017
This is a complete replacement of the Bowden Extruder for the XYZprinting Da Vinci 1.0 Pro printer with the exception of the Stepper Motor which is retained in its entirety.

Over time the original extruder weakened. The idler pulley loosened and became very noisy in operation. Finally, materials such as PTEG that require significant nozzle pressure to operate correctly began slipping between the idler pulley and the extruder gear causing the print to fail or under extrude.

The Da Vinci extruder assembly is also overly complicated and contains circuitry to detect the presence of filament ahead of the gear/idler pulley and a feedback circuit to presumably send filament movement back to the processor. Disconnecting both of these features has no apparent effect on the normal operation of the printer however during Load/Unload operations the printer will no longer detect the installation/removal of filament and the operator must manually signal the removal of the filament by pressing ENTER to the OK to Remove Filament on the front panel.

Printer:

XYZprinting Da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The extruder idler is under considerable constant pressure. Accordingly I recommend stronger materials such as ABS or PTEG rather than PLA.

Gain Access to Extruder Assembly

Remove and retain the following items:

  • Both Side Covers
  • Top Door
  • Front Panel
  • Top Aft Plastic Frame
Remove Extruder and retain or discard at your option:
  1. Unload Filament,
  2. Disconnect PTFE Tube from Connector on the aft printer frame,
  3. Remove small inside extruder cover,
  4. Remove Filament and Motion PCB,
  5. Remove Plastic PCB Mount,
  6. Remove Idler Tension Spring,
  7. Remove Idler Assembly,
  8. Remove 3 Screws holding the Extruder Stepper Motor to the frame,
  9. Remove Extruder Metal Flange.
Removed and Retired OEM Extruder Parts Assemble Extruder Block
  1. Install PTFE Connector into the hole provided in the front of the lower Extruder Bottom,
  2. Install Idler Bearing between two Lever halves,
  3. Install Bearing and Lever assembly into lower Extruder Bottom,
  4. Position Spring in Extruder Bottom groove,
  5. Insert M3x20 Spring Adjuster Screw and Hex nut into the Spring Adjuster Body,
  6. Install Spring Adjuster Cap into lower Extruder Bottom groove between the Spring and the end of the groove with the flange up,
  7. Install the Extruder Top onto the Extender Bottom positioning the Spring Adjuster Cap flange into the Extruder Top slot,
  8. Insert 3 M3x30 Screws through the Extruder Top and into the Extruder Bottom,
  9. Install a new Drive Gear on the Stepper Motor Shaft teeth side down and tighten set screw as required. The Stepper Motor shaft should be recessed approximately 0.9mm from the top of the Extruder Gear,
  10. Position the Stepper Motor assembly through the hole in the aft printer frame and hold in place,
  11. Mount the assembled Extruder to the stepper motor by hand tightening each screw in turn. Tighten with hex drive as required. Insure the Extruder Bottom is flush with the frame. If necessary remove additional plastic from the recessed flange boss on the underneath of the Extruder Bottom.
    NOTE:
    Do not over torque the screws. Doing so may strip the Stepper Motor threads!
  12. Test feed a short filament from back to front. Adjust Gear position on the Stepper Motor shaft so that the filament feeds smoothly through the Extruder Bottom into the center of the Gear grove. The will require temporary removal of the Extruder Assembly to gain access to the Gear set screw..
  13. Connect the PTFE tube removed in the steps above into the Connector installed above.
Extruder Filament Drive Gear Reassemble Printer
  1. Install Aft Printer plastic Top Frame
  2. Install Front Panel Cover,
  3. Install Side Covers,

  4. Install Top Door.

    NOTE:
    I have left the inside Extruder Cover off because the upped fasteners attach to the PCB Mount which has been removed. If it is desirable to install this cover, locally fabricate a mounting bracket and install cover to that bracket.

Test
  1. Insert Filament into the small aft hole in the lower Extruder Body until it touches the Gear,
  2. Select Load Filament on the printer front panel,
  3. Printer should grasp the filament and slowly pull it into the PTFE tube,
  4. Once the Hot End reaches the temperature set for loading filament, the Stepper Motor will advance the filament and extrude the normal amount,
  5. Confirm the filament has been loaded on the front panel.

Modifications to an Existing Design

This Bowden Extruder is based on a design by DWONH. The original design split the Extruder Body in half horizontally. This allowed both halves to be printed without support.

I changed the design to incorporate the filament channel and the Bowden Tube Connector hole in the bottom body. This allow a more precise line bore of the filament path and a more secure attachment of the Bowden Tube Connector.

The Extruder Body exterior was resized to fit onto the Da Vinci 1.0 Pro top aft frame with the covers installed.

The input filament hole was enlarged to optionally allow insertion of a PTFE feed tube that routes the filament from the spool to the Extruder.

The Lever Halves were reworked to more precisely fit the Idler Spring and Idler Bearing.

Interior geometry was reworked in several places to give more room for the Idler and Lever.

Bill of materials
  • 3 M3x30 Screws
  • 3 M3 Washers
  • 1 M3 Hex Nut
  • 1 M3x20 Screw
  • 1 Compression Spring, Steel, Metric, 9.6 mm OD, 1.6 mm Wire Size, 12.6 mm Compressed Length, 21.5 mm Free Length, 211.82 N Load Capacity http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005S4F93Q
  • 1 Double Sealed Precision Ball Bearing (688ZZ) 8 x16 x5 http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FE2EVLW
  • 1 MK7 Stainless Steel Teeth Extruder Gear With 5mm Bore & 40 Teeth http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B016XTZ5AQ
  • 1 PC4-M10 Male Straight Pneumatic PEFE Tube Push Fitting http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01IB81IHG

comments.author: Foxtrot3715

comments.text: Check to see if the filament is slipping on the drive gear.  Generally even when the filament slips it is not noisy like the original Extruder but you need to determine whether or not it is slipping.  The second thing to determine is whether or not extruder parts are touching the Extruder Gear or Idler Bearing.  This could be been caused by a poor quality print of the parts.  Finally make sure the Extruded Gear is mounted teeth down and is adjusted vertically to line up with the filament path.  If the alignment is off slightly, the filament can ride up on the side of the gear groove and the sound you hear may be the filament slipping back down.

title: Proxxon Micromot to 2040 rail mounts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a set of mounts to attach a Proxxon 12v micromot to t-slot rail, like MakerSlide, Misumi 2040, or 80/20 metric 2040.

• Print the part.
  • put an m5 nut in the square slot by the holes.
  • Add 10 or 12 mm long m5 screws, nuts, and washers as appropriate.
  • insert your proxxon micromot.
    • Viola! Update -- sorry, I had 2 bottoms uploaded. It should be 1 top and 1 bottom. You need both pieces to work.
    I've also made some minor changes vs the one I've printed and used. I've made the nut slots smaller, to prevent rotation of the m5 nuts, and I've made the side mounts shorter to provide room for the makerslide wheels behind the mount. Previously, I was sanding the part to allow room for the wheels. This version should work without needing any clean-up. If someone prints it, please confirm that the wheels move freely without sanding the part in this version. Also -- you must use button head bolts on the side of makerslide, or the head will conflict with the head mounting the makerslide wheel. Niether of these changes are needed if using Misumi or 80/20. You can see the parts in use on this youtube video:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-cek6AxIg1w Thanks!

comments.text: I'm using a Micromot 50.  This adapter should work with both the 50 and the 50EF, though I haven't tried the EF.  It's the 12-volt micromot without speed control.  The EF is 12 volts with speed control.
